Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Remediating E-waste Problems by Considering Consumer Behavior in Design for Multiple Life Cycles and Design for Ease of Return

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Electronic waste (e-waste) is one of the fastest growing pollution problems in the US and worldwide. With increasing population and increasing per capita product penetration rates, the e-waste stream continues to grow by close to 5 percent annually, three times faster than any other type of municipal waste. One solution to this problem is to recover discarded electronics from consumers for refurbishment or material recovery. However, there are a number of reasons that make product recovery in the US unprofitable including the cost of collection, the quality of received products (which may be stored for months, or even years, in a variety of non-optimal home environments), product obsolescence, and an inability to plan due to a lack of data about expected number of products being returned. These problems can be alleviated by having more information about the number and timing of used products available for collection from end users. This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award supports fundamental research to quantify the impact of design features and consumer behavior on the total volume, timing and quality of returned discarded items as well as the uncertainties in the return flows. Additionally, the research will assess consumer preferences and changes in consumer interests over time in order to design sustainable products that not only can meet the needs of the first consumer but also are re-marketable to satisfy the requirements of future consumers.

This research has two main objectives. First, it will provide a fundamental understanding of the role of consumer behavior and designer decisions on the amount of discarded electronics annually generated nationwide. More accurate estimation of the amount of discarded devices will assist in developing systems and infrastructure that facilitate e-waste collection and recovery processes. Second, the research will create a novel class of design evaluation techniques with the aim of creating artifacts that ensure long term solutions to control waste. The research team will use three groups of methods to accomplish these aims: (1) Design for multiple life cycles: incorporating preferences of several stakeholders or product owners in the early stage of design, (2) Design for dynamic preference: modeling market demand of a specific design alternative based on changes in consumer preferences and choices over time, and (3) Design for ease of return: Incorporation of the interests of channel members (e.g., recyclers or collectors), distributors and final consumers when designing a product.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Objectives: Inspired by the large amount of electronics sold and the e-waste generated annually, the project had two main objectives: (1) to gain a fundamental understanding of the role of consumer behavior and designer decisions on the amount of discarded electronics generated nationwide annually, (2) to develop a novel class of design evaluation techniques with the aim of creating product designs that ensure long-term solutions to control waste.

Research Outcomes: This GOALI project was a partnership between the University at Buffalo (UB) and experts from the remanufacturing industry. The partnership provided an opportunity for collecting valuable industry datasets that could help the research team prove the role that consumers play in generation and disposal of used electronics. A combination of analytical models informed by industry datasets have been used to analyze four different types of consumer behavior: (1) consumer’s product-storing behavior, (2) consumer product usage behavior, (3) repair behavior, and (4) return or disposal behavior.

In addition to the role of consumers, the research team studied the impact of product design policies. The overall goal was to identify the role that thoughtful, upfront design plays in avoiding future electronic waste issues. Industry datasets help the research team to study the role of design features in consumer’s decision to repair broken used electronics and quantify business outcomes of designing durable and repairable products for both manufacturers and consumers. In addition, several analyses have been conducted to connect the product usage phase with the design phase and employ products lifecycle data to modify product design features, and further connect product design with end-of-use phase and predict the future reusability of used electronics based on their design features and their profile of usage during the use phase of the products (e.g. predicting the future reusability of laptop batteries based on how students have charged and discharged their batteries in the past).

A wide range of research outcomes has been achieved. For example, the factors underlying the consumer’s product-storing behavior of end-of-use electronic devices ranging from product design features to data security concerns have been identified. Average storage time, average product age and upper bound of usage time have been estimated for retuned used products to an e-waste collection facility. The amount of incentives that trade-in programs could offer to motivate consumers to return their products to the waste stream has been calculated. Consumers’ willingness-to-pay for repair services has been estimated and business outcomes of designing durable products have been quantified for manufacturers. The outcomes from this research have provided important insights for recycling and remanufacturing companies, manufacturers, and designers regarding strategies to improve e-waste collection process which could lead to more efficient e-waste take-back systems and collection facilities nationwide.

Sixteen journal papers, twelve peer-reviewed conference papers, five conference presentations, and two poster presentations have resulted from this project.

Educational outcomes: Five PhD, eight Master’s, and seven undergraduate students have worked on the objectives of this grant over three years. The students have been participating in an interdisciplinary research team, have had the chance to collaborate with industry experts, and have presented their work at academic conferences. In addition, some of the students have visited industry partner facility and presented their research to the industry experts. In addition to students in our research team who directly were involved in the research activities, the students in two courses taught at UB have had the opportunity to learn about the findings of this project. The project findings have been integrated into two graduate/undergraduate courses: Decision-based Design and Sustainable Manufacturing. These courses are cross-listed between Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering department and Industrial and Systems Engineering department at UB.
